Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Rational Design, Synthesis and Understanding of Heteronanostructures as Photoelectrodes for Water Splitting
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The performance of advanced energy conversion devices, including that for solar water splitting, is ultimately connected to the design of the electrode materials at the nanoscale. Current research in this area is limited by how much one can tailor the intrinsic properties of existing materials and the slow progress in discovering novel materials. Supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program within the Division of Materials Research, this proposal will address the challenge by designing, preparing and understanding a new class of nanonet-based materials. The project will build on the PI's past success in making nanostructures with heterogeneous interfaces by studying combinations that include TiSi2 nanonets, which are unique two-dimensional nanostructures discovered by the PI's lab that offer suitably high surface areas and high conductivities, and a variety of oxide semiconductors such as TiO2, WO3 and Fe2O3. Specifically, the PI aims at solving the problems of poor charge diffusion within these oxides. The improved charge collection will reduce the undesired accumulation of photogenerated charges and thereby increase the photon-to-electron-conversion efficiencies. The study will focus on understanding how the electronic properties of nanostructures are influenced by their morphologies and compositions. Experimental techniques to be employed include chemical vapor deposition (for the creation of TiSi2 nanonets), atomic layer deposition (for the conformal coating of oxide semiconductors around the nanonets), various electrochemical methods, and a host of structural characterization procedures. These experiments will produce information on the crystallinity, the electronic property and the chemical property of the nanostructures, which will be essential to not only water splitting but also a number of related energy conversion and storage processes where charge transport plays an important role.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The ability to harvest solar energy and use it directly to produce hydrogen by splitting water has the potential to meet the energy needs without a negative impact on the environment. Due to the lack of suitable materials, this research is currently progressing at a slow pace. The proposed project will introduce a fundamentally new design that may advance the field significantly and make solar water splitting practical. The key to this design is a unique two-dimensional nanonet structure the PI's lab has discovered. When combined with oxide semiconductors, the nanonets can provide a dedicated charge transport pathway that should enable high-efficiency solar water splitting. The research efforts will be augmented by a fully integrated novel education program that aims at disseminating information on clean energy technology. The outreach program will take advantage of the popularity of Boston College's football games. The PI's team will participate in the FanFest event, which attracts a large number of alumni and visitors including K-12 students, by demonstrating how clean energy can be produced and used. A summer program will also be established to invite one to two science teachers each year from local high schools to conduct research on the proposed topics and gain hands-on experience which they will be able to share with their students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

The award enabled a detailed study on hematite (α-Fe2O3) as a promising photoelectrode material for solar energy harvesting.  The appealing uniquenesses of hematite include its abundance, stability against photocorrosion and non-toxicity.  The challenges faced by hematite when used for solar water splitting are its poor light absorption near the band edge, short minority charge diffusion distance and poor catalytic activity toward water oxidation.  To solve the problems associated with short charge diffusion distance, we introduced a charge transport component to facilitate charge collection.  The component is nanostructured and is highly anisotropic, which ensures sufficient light absorption without comprising charge collection.  To address the concerns of poor catalytic activities, we deposited water oxidation catalysts onto hematite and observed significantly improved performance.  Structural characterizations also identified surface defects that were previously unknown.  These states are responsible for the low photovoltages of hematite.  We fixed these states using a re-growth strategy and measured the highest photovoltage on hematite.  Together we demonstrated an unassisted solar water splitting system with hematite as the anode and Si as the cathode.  The overall solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency was 0.91%.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Water splitting promises a solution to the challenges associated with the intermittent nature of solar energy.  Among the technologies that can split water, photoelectrochemistry holds the greatest potential in terms of high efficiency and low cost.  Its development has been limited by the availability of electrode materials with suitable properties.  By studying a prototypical material of hematite, our project sheds light on materials-related issues important to high efficiency solar water splitting.  More important, the proposed strategies of additional material platforms and surface regrowth solve the most critical issues that limit the performance of hematite.  Not only did we measure record performance, a new knowledge base is also generated.  We gained new insight on the importance of controlling the surface properties to the overall performance of a photoelectrode material.  The insight will have significant impact on materials-related research for solar energy harvesting.

 

Broader impacts:

Understanding and controlling electrode materials properties are of paramount iimportance to a number of technologies, including fuel cells and solar cells.  The knowledge generated by this project is transferrable to other materials and other systems.  For instance, the charge recombination issue within the bulk as reported by us on hematite has already been observed on sulfide materials as well.  The limitations of photovoltages due to surface defects as observed on hematite have also been reported on other metal oxides such as BiVO4.  The implementation of the research efforts was complemented by our educational and outreach efforts.  New curricula focused on materials and renewable energy research have been developed at the host institution (Boston College) by the PI.  A novel outreach program aimed at introducing science to gamegoers during Boston College's home game days was developed and received overwhelmingly positive response.  A total of 22 students have been directly or indirectly enaged in the project, 6 of whom have been directly funded by the project, including 5 Ph.D.'s graduated from the project.
